title: USS Decker
text:
USS "Decker" (DE-47) was an <a href="Evarts%20class%20destroyer%20escort">Evarts class destroyer escort</a> constructed for the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. She was sent off into dangerous North <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> waters to protect <a href="convoys">convoys</a> and other ships from German <a href="submarines">submarines</a> and fighter <a href="aircraft">aircraft</a>. She performed escort and <a href="antisubmarine">antisubmarine</a> operations in battle areas before sailing home victorious at the end of the conflict.
Originally intended for transfer to <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> as BDE-47, "Decker" was launched on 24 July 1942 by the <a href="Philadelphia%20Navy%20Yard">Philadelphia Navy Yard</a>; retained for use in the USN; redesignated "Decker" (DE-47) on 4 March 1943; and commissioned on 3 May 1943, <a href="Lieutenant%20Commander">Lieutenant Commander</a> A. B. Adams, Jr. in command.
Namesake.
Ernest Elden Decker was born on 15 September 1913 in <a href="Portland%2C%20Maine">Portland, Maine</a> He enlisted in the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Reserve">United States Naval Reserve</a> on 14 September 1940. <a href="Lieutenant%20%28junior%20grade%29">Lieutenant (junior grade)</a> Decker was killed in action in the <a href="Solomon%20Islands">Solomon Islands</a> on 5 September 1942 when his ship was sunk in an engagement with <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> ships.
Service history.
World War II.
After escorting two oilers from <a href="Newport%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Newport, Rhode Island</a> to <a href="Galveston%2C%20Texas">Galveston, Texas</a> from 9–24 July 1943, "Decker" reported at <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a> on 20 August for <a href="convoy">convoy</a> duty. From 26 August 1943 – 26 April 1945, she gave vital support to operations in <a href="North%20Africa">North Africa</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, and <a href="Southern%20France">Southern France</a> by guarding the passage of nine supply convoys to <a href="Casablanca">Casablanca</a>, <a href="French%20Morocco">French Morocco</a>; <a href="Bizerte">Bizerte</a>, <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>; <a href="Palermo">Palermo</a>, <a href="Sicily">Sicily</a>; and <a href="Oran">Oran</a>, <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>. On 11 May 1944, at sea as part of the screen of UGS-40 bound for Tunisia, she aided in repelling a heavy <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> attack by enemy planes.
After overhaul at <a href="Charleston%2C%20South%20Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>, "Decker" operated in the <a href="Florida%20Keys">Florida Keys</a> as a <a href="School%20ship">training vessel</a> until the end of the war.
"Decker" received one battle star for World War II service.
Post-War.
On 28 August 1945, she was leased to the <a href="Republic%20of%20China">Republic of China</a>. "Decker" was returned from <a href="Lend-Lease">Lend-Lease</a> and transferred permanently to China on 7 February 1948 and renamed ROCS "Tai Ping" (F-22; ). ROCS "Tai-ping" was one of the four warships sent by the <a href="Republic%20of%20China%20Navy">Republic of China Navy</a> on 6 November 1946 to claim islands within the <a href="South%20China%20Sea">South China Sea</a> region. On 12 December 1946 "Tai Ping" arrived at Itu Aba island, becoming the first Chinese government ship ever to visit the Spratly Islands. (An American force had landed on Itu Aba in November 1945 and discovered that the wartime Japanese garrison had departed. A French warship, the FR "Chevreuil" had landed a team on Itu Aba in October 1946, two months before the Tai-ping arrived.) The Chinese government gave Itu Aba the Chinese name of <a href="Taiping%20Island">Taiping Island</a> in honour of the ship.
On 13 February 1951, She joined the <a href="blockade">blockade</a> fleet under the direct order of <a href="President%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20China%23History">ROC President</a> <a href="Chiang%20Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a> to capture and confiscate the <a href="Norway">Norwegian</a> civilian freighter "<a href="Capture%20of%20Tanker%20Tuapse%23Background">Hoi Houw</a>" at "" within the Japanese territory of <a href="Yaeyama%20Islands">Yaeyama Islands</a>. On 14 November 1954, four <a href="Communist">Communist</a> Chinese <a href="motor%20torpedo%20boat">motor torpedo boat</a> sank "Tai Ping" north of the <a href="Tachen%20Islands">Tachen Islands</a>. All but 28 of the 200 officers and crew were reported rescued by ships and seaplanes.
